The thyroid story begins with rabbits. In 1928, Dr. Chesney studied rabbits in the cellars of the Hopkins Clinic. More specifically, syphilis in rabbits. Regarding syphilis, he did not discover anything, but he found something extraordinary about thyroid. In rabbits that were closed for longer time in the lab cages, thyroid swelling often developed. To put it simply, thyroid activity decreased. Dr. Chesney was not able to link the effect with syphilis. With captured rabbits, the thyroid increased 20 times. The colloid in which the thyroid hormones are formed was slowly disappearing and immune cells were accumulated in it. Metabolism in infected rabbits, compared to rabbits in the wild, decreased by 17%. Freedom is very important for thyroid health (1). What was also important was the cabbage that the rabbits enjoyed. Finally, Dr. Chesney completed and at the same time discovered the first thyroid enhancer (goitrogen) in healthy diet: cabbage (1; 2). Until August 5th, 1941, a number of foods containing thyroid enhancers were identified in lab rabbits. Here are the main 7 (1; 3):
  1. cabbage,
  2. soya,
  3. mustard,
  4. rapeseed seeds,
  5. to a lesser extent broccoli, cauliflower and kale
 and their seeds. In the book you will find out about the latest research and medical science of foods and thyroid enhancers. Today, we assume that thyroid enhancers are also in some very popular healthy foods today. In all this, it is important that you realize that each individual is unique and needs a unique medical approach. We recommend testing different things and not blindly following one truth.

The more we sank into the intestines of making the book, the more it became clearer. The thyroid is largely the center of health, and not just this, it is a public health problem. The thyroid is sensitive to the slightest fluctuations in the environment. Your thyroid is sensitive to bad air, substances in water, substances in milk and meat that come through animal feed. That is, it is not enough that you are careful only in your healthy diet and healthy lifestyle . . . It is important that you move enough to be physically active every day and to make healthy choices in the nutrition. It is also important to know what kind of food the animals eat, whose milk we drink and the meat we eat. What will you find in the book? The first part of the book is dedicated to medical articles in which you will learn about Hashimoto, autoimmunity, metabolism and cholesterol, the replacement of thyroid hormone. At the end of each article, you get practical advice on health and healthy nutrition that you can use immediately. The second part is dedicated to a 7-day thyroid menu that you can test and see how it affects your well-being and thyroid hormones. For now, nutrition science in thyroid glands remains in laboratories. One of the reasons for this is that the science of health is still in the background of the science of medications; but this is changing now and more and more doctors decide and put a healthy lifestyle in the first place. In the third part you will get 11 prescriptions that will stimulate your thyroid to work better. Recipes are prepared according to the science of this book. In the fourth part, you will get a Thyroid Guidebook. The most important part of the book. It is important especially because it puts practicality in the first place and collapses all the information about food and lifestyle items into one place that you can use immediately. You can look at the thorough manual at any time, scroll through it and make a nutrition decision on its basis. I wish you a pleasant reading of the book. Love with your heart, and be healthy, Uroš

Laboratory results: fT4 = (free thyroid hormone in the blood), or shortly, thyroid hormone (thyroxine). Normal value: 9-23 thyroid points (pmol/l) fT3 = (free T3 hormone in the blood, triiodothyronine). fT4 is converted to fT3 in tissues, which has a stronger effect. This thyroid hormone is responsible for most of the effects of the thyroid gland on the human. Normal value: 4, 0-8, 3 thyroid points (pmol/l) BMI = body mass index. Calculate it by dividing the weight in kilograms twice by the height in meters. For example, 72 / 1. 7 = 42. 3 and 42. 3 / 1. 7 = 24. 9. ITM is therefore 24. 9. Normal ITM is between 18. 5 and 25. It is optimal in the upper part of the normal. TSH = thyroid-stimulating hormone Normal value: 0. 4-4 thyroid points (mU/ l) Slightly elevated value: 4-10 thyroid points (mU/ l) Strongly elevated value: above 10 thyroid points (mU/ l) Levothyroxine = thyroid replacement hormone (commercial names Synthroid, Euthyrox) Normal iodine value in adults: 150-249 points (mcg/L)

Below you will find out about the difference between natural and synthetic thyroid hormone, Hashimoto thyroiditis, the relationship between diabetes and thyroid, determination of thyroid hormones, iodine, calcitonin and many other things prepared by our coauthors. You can read about our co-authors in acknowledgements. At the end of each chapter you have discoveries that we have drawn together with the team from 158 medical researches which represent the latest medical and nutritional science in the field of thyroid. In this section, you will learn everything you need to know about thyroid from different perspectives. A lot of work has been invested in this part and is especially important to get all the information you need about your thyroid. Knowledge is one of the most important things for your health. In ignorance, problems begin to appear, but when you begin to acquire knowledge yourself, things begin to turn for the better. So: surgically accurate information for your thyroid. ------------------------------ Discovery: Normal TSH: 0, 4-4 thyroid points Slightly elevated TSH: 4-10 thyroid points Strongly elevated TSH: above 10 thyroid points Silent thyroid (preclinical hypothyroidism): normal FT4 (thyroid hormone), elevated TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone). 5-10% of people have it, so it is quite common, and affects metabolism in the body. L-thyroxine therapy with TSH above 10 thyroid points in people under 65 years of age without symptoms (1). Goal of treatment of thyroid with L-thyroxine: TSH = 0. 4-2. 5 thyroid point (2; 3). TSH hormone between 4 and 7 is normal at an older age (over 80 years). TSH increases with aging.

cpart: Natural thyroid hormone vs. synthetic hormone
content:
I started writing articles four years ago. Besides believing in a healthy lifestyle as the best medicine for today's illness . . . one of the reasons is also to bring clarity to today's medical confusion. What you hear on the Internet, on television, and reading in magazines is really confusing! Today, I will tell you about the difference between the synthetic replacement treatment of thyroid irregularity and natural replacement treatment. The difference between Euthyrox (Levothyroxine) and Armour (dried animal thyroid powder), of which it is widely spoken today. A new insight into medicine! From the beginning! The goal of alternative hormone treatment is to correct the irregular thyroid function. If your thyroid hormone drops, it is similar to that if somebody undercut the floor under your feet. Symptoms come slowly. Depression, fatigue, lack of energy, etc. (increased cholesterol!) . . . Thyroid hormone is a metabolic hormone, the hormone that regulates other hormones is the thermostat of your body . . . that is, we must constantly have a sufficient amount of thyroid hormone in the blood. There are two thyroid hormones in the body. T4 (thyroxine) and T3 (triiodothyronine). We monitor thyroid activity by measuring TSH. Your goal is to get your TSH to the upper normal limit between 2. 5 and 3. 0 thyroid points. If your TSH is elevated and you have problems that are related to the thyroid, it is prudent to talk to your doctor to edit and adjust the therapy. So the dose is increased. If your thyroid hormone is not regulated, then it is difficult to care for your health in a different way. Similar as in depression. If you see the world through black-and-gray glasses, it is hard to think about how well you do your homework, the next exam, be positive on coffee with your friends, or go to the hills to get some fresh air. The thyroid hormone is so important! Unfortunately, the we do not know how to or cannot treat decreased thyroid function (hypothyroidism, Hashimoto) causally. Thyroid tissue (follicles in it) breaks down and there is no more hormone (we may be able to treat thyroid failure in the future with stem cell transplantation). So we need to start to replace the thyroid hormone. A little before, I mentioned that there are two ways of replacing thyroid hormone. Synthetic thyroid hormone (levothyroxine, Euthyrox) and natural thyroid hormone (Armour). Today, this is most often dried pig thyroid extract. Sometimes it was also a cow's thyroid. It all started in 1891, when a gentleman with the name Murray first discovered that hypothyroidism can be treated with an extract of thyroid. And so the treatment of decreased thyroid function started. If you take a pig thyroid or a cow thyroid, grind it and turn it into powder, it will contain different substances. It will contain T4 thyroid hormone and T3 thyroid hormone and some other inactive substances. The first difference between synthetic hormone and the natural one is therefore that natural one contains T3 thyroid hormone as well (which is not necessarily good because it can cause an increased amount of this hormone in the blood). Treatment with a “natural” preparation (this is not exactly salad, that is why the quotation marks) continued until 1960, when synthetic thyroid hormone (levothyroxine) was discovered, and it slowly began to replace the natural one. Why? There are quite a few reasons. Firstly. When preparing natural thyroid replacement hormone preparations (eg. Armour), you cannot accurately know how much of the T4 and T3 hormone a certain part of the tissue contains. This means that if you take this medication today, you will get a certain amount of hormone, and if you take it tomorrow, you will get a different amount of hormone (1). If the target TSH values for treating thyroid dysfunction at the upper limit are between 2. 5 and 3. 0 thyroid points, this means that this level of hormone is very difficult to maintain in the blood. And it is important that you keep your TSH at this level! The second problem is that many more cases of overdose appear. There are cases when you have an excessive amount of thyroid hormone in the blood, which is, again, not good. The lower limit of TSH in the blood is 0. 5 thyroid points. It is also not good if TSH suppression occurs. This happens, for example, in the increased functioning of the thyroid, in Graves' disease (we call the symptoms a thyroid storm because it actually is a storm). Strong heartbeat, weakness, confusion, weight loss, restlessness, increased appetite, etc. But the long-term effects are mainly problematic. In the long run, an increased amount of thyroid hormone in the blood leads to osteoporosis and heart problems. For this reason, most endocrinologists do not want to hear about “natural” thyroid hormones. Another scientific discovery that has led to the use of a synthetic thyroid hormone that you can take today if you have thyroid problems is that most T3 hormones originate from the T4 hormone after leaving your thyroid gland. So T3 hormone is not that important. It is important for the functioning of the body – it is stronger than the T4 hormone! However, the body can produce it itself from T4 hormone (from thyroxine – thyroid hormone). In order to replace the thyroid hormone, it is enough to enter the T4 hormone into the body – that is, levothyroxine or Euthyrox. They have also found that both forms of treatment are approximately equally effective, but in the long run, treatment with synthetic hormones is much easier to control (osteoporosis, heart problems). And so natural treatment of decreased thyroid function slowly went into oblivion – until today's boom, caused by bad media information. If you have a thyroid problem, TAKE SYNTHETIC THYROID HORMONE. Do not listen to the nonsense about the “natural” thyroid treatment. The role of alternative hormonal treatment is precisely what “alternative” means. Replacing hormones. And nothing more. You have to have normal thyroid hormones so that you can focus on things that are really important for your health. Healthy lifestyle. Healthy food! Medications are a support and nothing more. Taking natural hormones can be considered for people who have problems with synthetic hormone. But these are very few. If you have hypothyroidism (Hashimoto), decreased thyroid function: - Follow your doctor's instructions for taking thyroid replacement hormone. - If you have elevated TSH, and symptoms of thyroid dysfunction: fatigue, depression, sensitivity to cold, body weight gain, constipation, strong menstruation, hoarse voice, forgetfulness, muscle pain), you must contact your doctor to optimize your therapy. The upper normal limit of TSH is between 2. 5 and 3. 0. Because you may not be depressed or tired for the last month due to problems with your husband or wife, but also because of your thyroid! Thyroid hormone absorption is best on an empty stomach (in the morning before breakfast) and worse along with fibre-rich food (healthy nutrition!). Lastly, do not worry over it. Long-term health depends on your lifestyle. On devoting 15 minutes per day to exercise and consuming healthy nutrition! ------------------------------ Discovery:

The connection between diabetes and thyroid:

Elevated insulin level that circulates through the blood stimulates thyroid growth and reduces the level of thyroid hormone (1; 2). Normal insulin level, on an empty stomach: < 25 insulin points (mIU/l) < 174 insulin points (pmol/l)

Are you tired, sleepy, apathetic, and depressed? Your

head aches, your voice is hoarse and it is difficult for you

to concentrate? One of the possible causes of these

problems is insufficient thyroid function.

The thyroid gland is one of the most important glands

with internal secretion. It is twined around our trachea,

right below the Adam’s apple.

Its task is to excrete thyroid hormones that are

indispensable for the growth, development and proper

functioning of our organs.

In addition, it plays an important role in regulating the

level of calcium in the body. In the literature, it is

possible to read that the thyroid produces ONE

TEASPOON OF HORMONES within one year.

So, it is a real hormone factory. However, when it

excretes too few thyroid hormones, we talk about

insufficient thyroid function. Expertly, this is called

hypothyroidism.

The causes of hypothyroidism may be several. The most

common cause of hypothyroidism is Hashimoto's

thyroiditis. The disease was named after its discoverer, a

Japanese doctor, Hakaru Hashimoto. Thyroiditis means

inflammation of the thyroid gland. It is also known as

chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis or autoimmune

thyroiditis.

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease. What

does that mean? It means that your own immune system

recognizes your thyroid as a foreign object.

It starts to treat the thyroid as a virus or a bacterium that

harms us and needs to be destroyed. To this end, it

begins to produce antibodies directed against the

thyroid. The consequence is damage and inflammation

of the thyroid. All this slowly leads to a state where our

thyroid is no longer able to produce enough thyroid

hormones.

For now, we cannot yet fully explain why our own

defence system attacks the thyroid. The disease usually

progresses slowly and may be recognized late.

At the beginning, the disease does not usually cause

problems, and in this period it is often detected

coincidentally.

Eventually, however, as the disease progresses and the

lack of thyroid hormones goes worse, it is shown in a

very varied way.

You can have a headache, you feel tired, sleepy,

depressed, or you unexpectedly gain weight, your

digestion is decelerated, your voice is hoarse, you notice

various changes on your skin, etc.

But when do we think of hypothyroidism and

Hashimoto's thyroiditis? The disease is often difficult to

recognize due to numerous problems and gradual

deterioration.

Many of these problems are often attributed to stress

because of today's way of life, because of aging, or

because of another illness.

We should certainly think of insufficient thyroid function

when the above problems are present. You should go to

your personal doctor for unexplained, long-lasting

fatigue, if you have dry skin, pale and blurred face or if

you are constipated.

A suspected disease will be confirmed or denied by a

personal doctor with a simple blood test to determine the

values of the appropriate hormones and antibodies.

However, for a more detailed examination of the thyroid

and an accurate diagnosis, treatment with a specialist –

endocrinologist – is necessary.

Based on investigations, a thyroid doctor decides what

kind of treatment to apply. Treatment includes

replacement of thyroid hormone in the form of tablets.

This way, we replace the thyroid hormone deficiency

due to insufficient thyroid function. Regular blood

controls are required during treatment.

Without treatment, symptoms and signs may increase.

Thyroid enlargement can occur – so-called goitre. This

way, thyroid tries to replace hormone production which

is too low.

Do we have any influence on the course of the disease?

The course of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is difficult to

influence.

With a healthy lifestyle, we can alleviate the problems

that the disease causes and contribute to the better

functioning of our immune system. We can help

ourselves with proper physical activity and nutrition,

with enough rest and avoiding stress.

Discovery:

Connection between kilograms and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH):

The higher the body mass index, the higher the TSH.

From a research: if TSH is 1.19 points and ITM is 40.4 points,

at TSH 4.97 points ITM increases to 42.3 points (1).

When gaining weight, TSH can also be increased by 1-3 points.

Thyroid can be the cause of increased body weight, but it can also

be vice versa, that is, increased body weight results in thyroid defect.

The research Thyroid hormone in the blood (FT4) says that it can

be increased from 11.5 to 18.0 in weight reduction for 2 ITM

points.

I have a friend whom I have known since high school. As

if it was yesterday I remember the first school day, when

I noticed that she was carrying an unusual device around

her waist, which I had not seen before.

When we got to know each other better, she said that she

had had type 1 diabetes since childhood. The device on

her waist was nothing but an insulin pump, which

constantly measured blood sugar and provided insulin if

necessary.

As much as possible, the device imitated a defective

pancreas, which had already been attacked and

destroyed by my friend’s antibodies. Although it has

been many years since then, we have stayed in touch.

Recently, she confided in me with the finding of her

doctor that her thyroid does not function properly.

Last year, a study was carried out in the Netherlands

which showed that in children with type 1 diabetes

associated thyroid problems are 24 times more likely to

develop. These include both the under-functioning

thyroid, called hypothyroidism, as well as excessivelyfunctioning

thyroid action, which is called

hyperthyroidism.

Unfortunately, type 2 diabetes is also associated with

thyroid problems. In England, a research showed that

6.6% of men have some or all thyroid problems. The

second study showed that thyroid is giving problems to

as much as 12.3% of people with type 2 diabetes. In

diabetes, thyroid diseases occur more often, and vice

versa.

Thyroid is a gland, like pancreas. It is located at the front

of the neck and it releases hormones into the blood that

affect many of the functions in our body. Among other,

they accelerate growth, development of nervous system

and functioning of metabolism and heart.

Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease. This means

that the body itself attacks pancreas cells, causing an

insulin deficit. The most common cause of underactive

thyroid function is the body attacks it itself and either

destroys it or prevents the production of its hormones.

Therefore, the connection between type 1 diabetes and

malfunction of the thyroid is not unusual.

It is somewhat more difficult to explain the link between

thyroid problems and type 2 diabetes. The latter is more

common and appears most often in adults who live an

unhealthy lifestyle. Eating high-caloric food, bad food

(so-called “junk food”) and sedentary lifestyle have led to

the true epidemic of diabetes.

The link between the two illnesses is related to

atherosclerosis, increased pressure, and associated

cardiovascular diseases, which are more frequent in

diabetics. It is certainly necessary to add genes, which,

unfortunately, we cannot influence, to create a perfect

cocktail.

But, you know what gamblers say – bad cards do not

mean the end of the game. It is important to withstand

all factors that stimulate the onset of diabetes!

You have the final say in this. Just make sure it does not

stay in words only...

A healthy and nutritious meal, which contains as few

sugars as possible and is rich in fibre, should be at your

table every day. Also, let your every day be active!

Your body will gratefully thank you even for half an

hour of exercise a day. If you smoke, stop. If you are

thinking to start – do not start.

Also, try to stay as little as possible in an environment

where there is a lot of cigarette smoke. Passive smoking is

also extremely harmful.

These are the three principles that are essential for

starting a life-course that can be called “healthy”.

------------------------------

Discovery:

Connection between hunger hormone (leptin) and thyroid-stimulating hormone:

From the research: less than the thyroid works, the higher the level of

leptin in the blood; the higher the body mass index, the more leptin

in the blood increases.

From the research: if TSH is 1.19 points and leptin is 47.7

points, at a TSH level of 4.97 leptin increases to 64.0 points (1).
